qas.question: What is the resulting thick liquid called?
What does chyme mix with in the duodenum?

answers.text: digestive enzymes from the pancreas and bile juice from the liver

qas.question: Where does hyme go after the duodenum?
Where does 95% of absobtion of nutrients occur?

context: After some time (typically 1–2 hours in humans, 4–6 hours in dogs, 3–4 hours in house cats),[citation needed] the resulting thick liquid is called <a0_0>chyme<a0_0/>. When the pyloric sphincter valve opens, chyme enters the duodenum where it mixes with <a1_0>digestive enzymes from the pancreas and bile juice from the liver<a1_0/> and then passes through <a2_0>the small intestine<a2_0/>, in which digestion continues. When the chyme is fully digested, it is absorbed into the <a3_0>blood<a3_0/>. 95% of absorption of nutrients occurs in <a4_0>the small intestine<a4_0/>. Water and minerals are reabsorbed back into the blood in the colon (large intestine) where the pH is slightly acidic about 5.6 ~ 6.9. Some vitamins, such as biotin and vitamin K (K2MK7) produced by bacteria in the colon are also absorbed into the blood in the colon. Waste material is eliminated from the rectum during defecation.
